discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Example: Router(config-router)# neighbor 10.1.1.1 ttl-security hops 2
The example configuration sets the expected incoming TTL value to at least 253, which is 255 minus the TTL value of 2, and this is the minimum TTL value expected from the BGP peer. The local router will accept the peering session from the 10.1.1.1 neighbor only if it is 1 or 2 hops away. 

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios/12_2sx/feature/guide/fsxebtsh.html

Selected Answer: D
According to Cisco, the expected ping response from the neighbor should be 253 or greater because 255-253=2 or 255-254=1 which means that the neighbor is 2 or 1 hops away.

the expected incoming TTL value to at least 253
Reference: 
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios/12_2sx/feature/guide/fsxebtsh.html

It's D
--------------------------------------------------
neighbor 10.1.1.1 ttl-security hops 2
The example configuration sets the expected incoming TTL value to at least 253, which is 255 minus the TTL value of 2, and this is the minimum TTL value expected from the BGP peer. The local router will accept the peering session from the 10.1.1.1 neighbor only if it is 1 or 2 hops away.
--------------------------------------------------------------
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios/12_2sx/feature/guide/fsxebtsh.html#wp1059215

choices.A: to 2.2.2.2, with a TTL of 2 or more
choices.B: from 2.2.2.2, with a TTL of less than 2
choices.C: to 2.2.2.2, with a TTL of less than 253
choices.D: from 2.2.2.2, with a TTL of 253 or more

discussion.content: a stub area to leave the OSPF domain has only one default path, so the answer is D (default route)
what a weird worded question... had no clue what it was trying to say but after reading the answers it made a bit more sense.

Selected Answer: D
Default route is the only route generated by ABR to the totally stub area
D not A

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. If RC is a stub router, which entry must be injected so that it will send traffic outside the OSPF domain?

discussion.content:
1 - Validate the physical and data link layers of the 10gbps link
2 - Execute the channel-group number mode active command 
3 - Execute the lacp min-bundle 3 command 
4 - Validate the network layer of the 10Gbps link

1 - Validate the physical and data link layers of the 10gbps link - before anything we want to be sure that link is up and running at L1/L2

2 - Execute the channel-group number mode auto command - this is needed for LACP, only other option is ON so we need AUTO here for the LACP

3 - Execute the lacp min-bundle 3 command - they want the bundle out of service if one link is down

3 - Validate the network layer of the 10Gbps link - to check the network is still working at L3 over the LAG

comments.content:
LACP: Active/Passive
PAgP: Desirable/Auto
Static: On

On second thoughts, after the 10Gb link is in the bundle how can you validate just layer 3 specifically of the specific 10Gb link? 

Maybe the suggested answer is correct?

Validate the physical layer, the network layer (outside of bundle) and afterwards configure the channel-group to add it into the bundle and finally set the lacp min-bundle 3 command?

I was thinking, you must check the layer 3 of the bundle but there is no such option provided.

discussion.content:
1 - Validate the physical and data link layers of the 10gbps link - before anything we want to be sure that link is up and running at L1/L2
2 - Execute the channel-group number mode auto command - this is needed for LACP, only other option is ON so we need AUTO here for the LACP
3 - Validate the network layer of the 10Gbps link - to check the network is still working at L3 over the LAG
4 - Execute the lacp min-bundle 3 command - they want the bundle out of service if one link is down

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
A network engineer is adding an additional 10Gbps link to an existing 2x10Gbps LACP-based LAG to augment its capacity. Network standards require a bundle interface to be taken out of service if one of its member links goes down, and the new link must be added with minimal impact to the production network. Drag and drop the tasks that the engineer must perform from the left into the sequence on the right. Not all options are used.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

choices.C: ip prefix-list BGP-to-ospf seq 5 permit 22.22.22.0/24 router map BGP-To-OSPF permit 10 match ip address prefix-list BGP-to-ospf router ospf 1 redistribute bgp 100 metric 100 metric-type 1 subnet route-map BGP-To-OSPF
choices.B: ip prefix-list BGP-to-ospf seq 5 permit 22.22.22.0/24 router bgp 100 bgp redistribute-static route-map BGP-To-OSPF permit 10 match ip address prefix-list BGP-to-ospf router ospf 1 redistribute bgp 100 metric-type 2 route-map BGP-To-OSPF
choices.A: ip prefix-list BGP-to-ospf seq 5 permit 22.22.22.22/32 router bgp 100 bgp redistribute-internal route-map BGP-To-OSPF permit 10 match ip address prefix-list BGP-to-ospf router ospf 1 redistribute bgp 100 metric 100 metric-type 1 subnets route-map BGP-To-OSPF
choices.D: ip prefix-list BGP-to-ospf seq 5 permit 22.22.22.0/24 router map BGP-To-OSPF permit 10 match ip address prefix-list BGP-to-ospf router ospf 1 redistribute bgp 100 route-map BGP-To-OSPF

discussion.content: This question is shit you have to read the ans 10 times

Selected Answer: A
Whenever you redistribute from BGP to something else, BGP will only release externally learned routes. Even if you try to match things specifically with a route-map or the “match internal external” commands, BGP simply will not let them be redistributed.

In order to allow BGP to redistribute internal routes, you must explicitly command BGP to do it using the bgp redistribute internal command.
A - bgp redistribute-internal

Selected Answer: A
A is the only one with a /32, it's a no brainer
A. 
ip prefix-list BGP-to-ospf seq 5 permit 22.22.22.22/32 

 router bgp 100 bgp redistribute-internal 
 route-map BGP-To-OSPF permit 10 

 match ip address prefix-list BGP-to-ospf 
 router ospf 1 redistribute bgp 100 metric 100 metric-type 1 subnets route-map BGP-To-OSPF
B.
 ip prefix-list BGP-to-ospf seq 5 permit 22.22.22.0/24
 
 router bgp 100 bgp redistribute-static 
 route-map BGP-To-OSPF permit 10 

 match ip address prefix-list BGP-to-ospf 
 router ospf 1 redistribute bgp 100 metric-type 2 route-map BGP-To-OSPF
C.
 ip prefix-list BGP-to-ospf seq 5 permit 22.22.22.0/24 

 router map BGP-To-OSPF permit 10 
 match ip address prefix-list BGP-to-ospf 

 router ospf 1 redistribute bgp 100 metric 100 metric-type 1 subnet route-map BGP-To-OSPF
D. 
ip prefix-list BGP-to-ospf seq 5 permit 22.22.22.0/24 

 router map BGP-To-OSPF permit 10 
 match ip address prefix-list BGP-to-ospf 

 router ospf 1 redistribute bgp 100 route-map BGP-To-OSPF

ip prefix-list BGP-to-ospf seq 5 permit 22.22.22.22/32 
router bgp 100 
 bgp redistribute-internal 

route-map BGP-To-OSPF permit 10 
 match ip address prefix-list BGP-to-ospf 

router ospf 1 
 redistribute bgp 100 metric 100 metric-type 1 subnets route-map BGP-To-OSPF

A ip prefix-list BGP-to-ospf seq 5 permit 22.22.22.22/32 
router bgp 100 
bgp redistribute-internal
route-map BGP-To-OSPF permit 10 
match ip address prefix-list BGP-to-ospf 
router ospf 1 
redistribute bgp 100 metric 100 metric-type 1 subnets route-map BGP-To-

Refer to the exhibit. Router 1 and router 2 are running IBGP, and router 2 and router 3 are running OSPF Area 0.
